title: 115_s1764
content: The "Compassionate Access, Research Expansion, and Respect States Act of 2017" or the "CARERS Act of 2017" amends the Controlled Substances Act to allow compliance with state laws regarding medical marijuana. It also excludes cannabidiol from the definition of marijuana. SEC. 3 amends the Controlled Substances Act to exclude cannabidiol from the definition of marijuana, defining it as a substance derived from marijuana or synthetic formulation containing less than 0.3% delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol. SEC. 4 amends the Controlled Substances Act to allow states to determine if marijuana grown for cannabidiol production complies with concentration limits. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will terminate the Public Health Service interdisciplinary review process related to marijuana research. The Attorney General will issue at least 3 licenses for marijuana research within a year. Amendments will be made to the Controlled Substances Act for marijuana research. Amendments to the Controlled Substances Act include redesignating paragraphs, updating registration applications, and specifying regulations for marijuana research within 180 days. The Secretary will require practitioners to register for marijuana research if authorized to handle controlled substances and if their research protocol is approved by the Secretary or other federal agencies funding scientific research. The Secretary will grant registration for nonhuman research not federally funded if approved by the National Institutes of Health, unless it is against the public interest. Factors considered include the applicant's experience with controlled substances, compliance with laws, and behavior impacting public health and safety. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to include "marijuana" in the definition of "marihuana" for public health and safety. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will allow VA health care providers to give recommendations and opinions to veterans in states with marijuana programs, and complete related forms.
